title: Manual Playing Card Shuffler - Less plastic

description.text:
Modified parts for the awesome manual playing card shuffler from user RockstarAlchemist.
The goal of this remix was to reduce the amount of plastic needed, also to help make the shuffler a bit more efficient

--6-5-17--
Added a modified crankface and crankface backplate, they have less plastic and also I moved the holes for the bottom card guide to be a bit closer to each other to help align the cards as they fall.

--6-6-17--
Added "proper" crankface and crankface backplates, which should occupy less plastic and print faster. Moved the holes for the bottom card guide closer to each other to help align cards as they fall.
Also added another crankface backplate that had a hole for a card sled that you can "catch" the cards into.

remixed_from.author: luc_e
remixed_from.title: Raspberry Pi 7 Inch Touchscreen display case

title: T3CHKOMMIE Tab7
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've been wanting to make my own T3CHKOMMIE Tablet for years. Finally had the time and budget to CAD something that fits my style and usage. I wanted to make something that I could take with me no site for network security tests and vulnerability scans. Wanted something I could leave behind that could be battery powered if needed. After ALOT of thought and design I came up with the T3CHTab7

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lUxfOjKartA

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print everything facing up so you don't need supports. Depending on your bed level, you may want to consider using a brim. I used a 4 pass brim that prevented the parts from lifting

Post Processing

You are gonna need some hardware, most of the stuff I used, I had laying around.

  1. Print the face, bracket, back panel and 4 sets of stoppers (TPU).

  2. Get some "binding posts" from a hardware store. The holes in this model are 6mm in diameter and fit the 1" 8/32 aluminum binding posts from ACE Hardware. ($0.95/each)

  3. you need some short machine screws for the screen mount (I salvaged some from an old PSU case) and small screws for the display board mount (that should come with the screen kit)

  4. You need a RPI, a PowerBoost 1000C, 6600 mAh rechargable battery, two switches, The Offical Raspberry Pi 7 inch screen, and some female-to-female Jumpers. Most of this stuff I got on amazon, Adafruit also carries most, if not all of it.

  5. Solder one switch to EN and GND pins on the power boost (this will be the on/off switch)

  6. Put the other switch in between the 5v on the GPIO and the 5v on the display driver. (this switch will turn off the screen, usefull if you want to just use HDMI out on pi)

  7. Plug your two 5v leads (one to 5v out on powerboost 1000c and one to display switch) and plug the resulting grounds into ground pins on GPIO. you may want to carefully bend the pins on the GPIO with pliers for a better fit.

8.Double/triple check your connections and polarity!

Assembly

  1. Run the 4 binding posts through the face plate with the U shaped stoppers as washers and the circular stops are top caps. These washers put a nice soft surface between the binding posts and the back of the screen.

  2. Once the posts are secure, screw the screen into the face plate from behind. This keeps the mounting secure and clean.

  3. Slide bracket over 4 mounting posts. Mount switches, Pi, PowerBoost and charging circuit like the photos show. The fit will be a little tight, but you shouldn't need to force anything. Be careful with the PI mount, it is very tight and the small pin can break easily.

  4. when all parts are in and wires are secure, add the cover plate and screw together with the 4 screws that came with the binding posts.

title: Power grid  40 mm poker chips holder

description.text:
This is a dual extrusion poker chip holder for the board game Powergrid, now you can get rid of that annoying paper currency and use your poker chips and best of all these trays fit in the box since the chips are stored tilted.
There are 2 chip trays designs to hold the right amount of 40mm poker chips for the game, each column holds 20 chips, these being:
• 40 chips for 1 elektro value ( 2 stacks of 20 );
• 15 chips for 5 elektro value ( in order to keep the design uniform when you store the chips you need to add to this stack the 5 extra chips of 50 elektro, sou you will have a stacj of 20 chips stored in this column);
• 40 chips for 10 elektro value( 2 stacks on 20 );
• 25 chips for 50 elektro value ( 1 stack of 20 + those extra 5 that should be stored with the stack of 5's as explained).

If you don't own a dual extruder printer, just print everything with the same printer head (1 color) or don't add the lettering to the print ( that might require the use of some support for the hollow lettering).

comments.author: lukeconaway

comments.text: I based the design off of the Bair Arms bump fire device.  It snaps on to the trigger guard. You put your index finger between the curved section and the rifle trigger, your middle finger on the lower trigger, and pull forward with your other hand.  this pulls the trigger into your finger and fires, the recoil pushes the rifle back, and the trigger resets.  the pressure of you constantly pushing forward pushes the trigger into your finger again and it fires.  As long as you push forward, the rifle bounces back and forth and fires around 14 rounds per second.

title: e3d V6 Dual Hotend Mount for Ultimaker Type Printers

description.text:
First off, let me please ask that if you like these designs and find them useful please do like, follow and share my content. And if you have any ideas or concepts to modify the content I would love to hear!

I designed this print head to house dual e3d v6 all-metal hotends. It has inbuilt cable management, and can be adapted to most Ultimaker style printers. The linear bearings are press fit and held in with friction. I used this design for 100+ hours on my Mankati Full-scale XT before upgrading it to an aluminium Mankati Full-scale XT 'Plus' print head carriage. It worked well during it's operation within the Mankati Printer.

The fan mount clips to the dual e3d V6 hotend heatsinks and two 30mm fans are used for cooling.

There is a 'bolt through' version which has a different clamping method to the other piece.

I would like others to utilise the design, remodel/remake it and make use of something that I wish to share :)

If you have any comments, ideas or suggestions I would love to hear them!

Make your MBS Atom 90 mountainboard fully electric!
This has been through many revisions to make it easy to just bolt everything on to the existing bolt holes on an Atom 90 mountainboard. Works like a champion! Would work even better with 2 motors and ESC's (1 for each rear wheel).
Let me know what you think!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PecxJJL14kc&list=PLsCFjA1tOwXA20OKC3zw4jwajZJSEAKSG&index=1
See http://mrrocketman.com/blog/2014/01/27/electric-mountainboard-is-working/ for more details.
Added .par and .stp files
STLs are now repaired. Added left and right motor mounts.
Added Wheel Insert Inside For 54T Sprocket - courtesy of Mikko R!

Add a Turnigy SK3 motor, some LiPos or LiFe batteries, sprockets and chain, an ESC, and a remote control and you're electric.
Print at 50% or higher infill with ABS (Edit print this as 90% or higher infill. I just broke the 50% one haha). Trust me on this one. I've broken probably 5 on these that were PLA or 25% infill.
Oh, an don't bother trying to print with support material. It's way easier to just print without support material and clean up a couple little imperfections.
See http://mrrocketman.com/blog/2014/01/27/electric-mountainboard-is-working/ for more details.

title: DIY Spot Welder (Super Scary Weldy Thingy)

description.text: This build is quite complex but should be within the capabilities of makers who are interested in 3D printing, metal casting, metal machining, and general fabrication. It makes use of a re-purposed microwave oven transformer as a power source and some ancillary electrical parts such as a DC power supply for switching the transformer via a solid state relay, a digital timer for setting the weld interval, a salvaged DC cooling fan from a PC and a few switches. I have included ready made STL files for all the casting patterns as well as STEP files of the complete design. Both 2D and 3D drawings are available for the engineering drawings. I have tested the machine and it is capable of welding steel and stainless steel although the spot size has to be kept small (approx <2mm) to maintain the current density. It is worth checking out Youtube to research the methods used to rewind the transformer. Be warned though, this machine uses mains voltage and should only be attempted by those who are confident working with high voltage/high current electricity.

Printer:

OrdBot Hadron

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm per layer

Infill:

50%

Notes:

It is worth printing 1 to 2% oversize to allow for material shrinkage. I printed in PLA which is fine given that the patterns are only likely to be used once. If you intend to do batches of castings it is worth printing in ABS or nylon is even better

Preparation of the casting patterns

I will usually sand the prints as smooth as I can and then fill the surface with spray putty which can be purchased in a rattle can. The surfaces need to be smooth enough to hide the print layers. I then paint the spray putty with two coats of an automotive acrylic lacquer - doesn't matter what colour. This provides a hard slippery coating so that the green sand doesn't stick to the pattern.

CAD/CAM

The complete machine was modelled using Autodesk Inventor. The mechanism for the over centre clamp was exported as 2D DXF files and laser cut from 3mm acrylic. These parts were assembled using screws so that the geometry of the handles and clamp could be validated. Any parts that needed to be cast were then modified to create the machining allowances and draft angle so that the patterns could be withdrawn from the sand moulds. Where necessary the parts were split on an appropriate centre line and holes added for sprue pins to align the parts for moulding.

description.text:
This is my submission for the Chip-E remix challenge. When I first saw Chip-E walking, it reminded me of those ancient Japanese Karakuri tea serving automaton. It would be fun to see Chip-E act as a tiny servant. The base and midsection are modified to be able to attach the arms in case you want the arms higher or lower. If you want to use the base instead of the midsection for the arms, print the original midsection for Chip-E as the modified midsection may get in the way for the base.

The arms can be attached either side to side or holding the tray in the front. If the front tray is holding an object too heavy it might cause Chip-E to fall forward so there is a pair of slots in the back where you can insert some M6 nuts to offset the balance.

Also added a small cup and vase for fun along with trays with small cup holder ridges.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fxDQRkR4Bfl

title: Modified parametric rear sensor mount for new Anet A8

description.text:
This is a remix of TNS' s customizable rear mount https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2219963 to function on a new Anet A8 (April 2017 version with horizontal y-sensor). The original rear mount would cause the print head to hit the frame side before it reaches the sensor. The side cutouts allow the sensor full travel.
You will need to modify the Y distance to about 64mm instead of the stock 51.

The other issue with the original two clip version is that it would not allow my sensor (18mm inductive) to get close enough to the tray. I've therefore beefed up the clip using the existing parameters and only use one mounted on the lowest screw holes. It is very sturdy with PLA. I've included the customizer option so you can adjust to your needs.
Update: version 1.3 fixed issue where using a sensor size of 8mm did not create a working design.

Uses 2 3x10mm bolts for mounting.
Stock carriage settings:
define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 10
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 54

define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 60

(This is version 3 of the holder, I made some small adjustments to make the design stronger and to fit most bikes, enjoy!)

(OBS: if you want this bike holder without the powerbank compartment please follow this link: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2381406 )

(For version 4 of this holder please follow this link: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2514092 )

Bought a new e-bike (EcoRide) and wanted a holder for my phone (Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge with Spigen SlimArmor case.) so that I can use Navigation and S-health, as navigation with the phone in the pocket is a pain, not to mention dangerous.

I also have a E-thinker 10.000 mAh powerbank, and tought that if I combine the two I can also charge my phone at the same time, since using GPS consumes alot of power.

The holder is tied down with a couple of zip ties, see pictures.

Here is a link to the Spigen SlimArmor case I use: https://www.spigen.com/products/galaxy-s7-edge-case-slim-armor?variant=11972954241

My brother has the Spigen Neo Hybrid case, and it seems to work well, even though it seems to be a bit smaller:
https://www.spigen.com/products/galaxy-s7-edge-case-neo-hybrid?variant=12164611841

And in case you are interested in the powerbank I use, here is a link to it:
https://www.amazon.ca/THINKER%C2%AE-E7-10000mAh-Portable-External/dp/B00MM1L9FU

Please let me know if you like this holder, or if there is something that can be improved on.

I might make a version for Galaxy S7 edge without powerbank, if there is lots of demands for it, please let me know if there is?

Also I am thinking of a version that would fit an S7 Edge without a case, so let me know if anyone wants that?

title: Super Simple Belt Tensioner X & Y Axis Remix - Monoprice 3D Maker Select V2 and Wanhao

description.text:
I really liked this belt tensioner for the Wanhao/Monoprice i3's, but wanted to make it a bit more solid.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1784375

I kept the 1st part the same, but modified the part that connects to the carrier so that it holds the belt on both sides.

6/18/2017: I decided to modify this further, and make a Y axis tensioner with a similar design. For the X axis, you'll need to print the following:

1x X_Axis_Spacer.stl
1x i3_tensioner_2_REMIX_X_Axis.stl
1x i3_tensioner_REMIX.stl

For the y you'll need:

1x i3_tensioner_REMIX.stl
1x i3_tensioner_2_REMIX_Y_Axis.stl

The adjuster now slots into the base, for a more positive fit. I've printed these parts now in PLA, PETG, and ABS. I wouldn't recommend PLA, it's going to get too hot in both locations, might deform. I did have to adjust the stepper pulley on the Y and the idler pulley on the Y to straighten out the belt, but I may test a new version that puts the belt on the same side as the attachment point on the carrier. If that works out I'll update this again.

Also recommend only using 1 zip tie on each side of the belt, and keeping it close to the tensioner.

MakerBot

MakerBot Replicator 2

Bumper Bot Scyphozoa Domelia
Hello,my name is Jason Bakutis. I designed and built Bumper Bot to be a part of Makerbot's Robot Petting Zoo for the 2012 Maker Faire season.
Some of you may have already seen Bumper Bot in action. If so, then you also saw how much the children (of all ages) enjoyed his company.
Bumper Bot is a friendly species of robot. He patiently finds his way around, whistling as he goes. If something blocks his path, he finds another way around. He can also be programmed to perform a variety of tasks.
Oh yeah, he also has googly eyes, jets, and arcade buttons.
I designed Bumper Bot to be built by others, with intuitive, easy to follow, steps. He is engineered in a way that encourages modification, so it is really easy to give your Bot personality.
I look forward to the many awesome variations you all will come up with as you help populate the world with the next generation of Bumper Bots!
Created by Jason Bakutis

Bumper Bot is a simple project, with no need for an advanced understanding of electronics. However, there are areas that can be elaborated upon (i.e; the Arcade buttons), if you so choose.
The "engine" for the Bumper Bot is a Scribbler S2 robot by Parallax, which is able to be programmed by a 5th grader. Again, one has the freedom to "go deeper" using the free, open source S2 GUI.
The parts, all together, take somewhere between 50 and 60 hours to print (he's a biggie), but this is calculated with extra shells, so that can be shortened considerably. Not a single Bumper Bot suffered any damage after being handled by literally thousands of children, mostly in the 2-5 age group (!)
The actual assembly only takes, at most, 2 hours, and is a pleasurable experience (I should know, I built 5 of them).
Refer to the Bumper Bot Instructions.pdf for detailed assembly instructions.
Have Fun!
-Jason Bakutis

title: Monoprice Select Mini extended bed brackets
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Extended the bed brackets to utilize the 300x200mm Anodized Aluminum Y Carriage Plate XL Upgrade for Prusa i3.

I have not tested, printed or fit as I have yet or order the carriage plate. If successful it will use the carriage, heat bed and borosilicate glass from the prusa I3 for the monoprice select mini.

6/19/17: Changed a few things on the front rail after installation.

6/25/17: I added the wider bed rail mounts to fit 300mm 8mm rods but I ended up swapping out the rods for longer ones, 315mm and going with the standard size bed mounts. These fit and are usable but you may lose some bed space.

print_settings.Notes:: Using a brim helps with ABS. even with ABS slurry the fins try to pull up (ABS shrinkage). I lost one rocket this way. description.text:
The rocket is remixed via openSCAD using the source from:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:281036

The rocket launcher was modeled after the launcher in the videos from this make:
https://www.thingiverse.com/make:295823

Here are the values I used and why:
inner_diameter = 22.8; -- Fits over 1/2" PVC pipe
body_height = 180; //[10:100] -- Too short in Customizer, wanted a taller rocket.
nose_height = 50; //[2:100]
number_of_fins = 4; //[0:4]
fin_width = 30; //[2:50]
fin_height = 55; //[2:100]

/ [Extruder] /
// Width of a single wall/perimeter in mm - adjust to ensure model is sliced correctly

description.text:
Version 1.0 Dated: 29 June 2017.

This is a re-mix of Ulmenkott's E3Dv6 X Axis Carrier. The re-mix allows a BLtouch Auto Level Sensor to be mounted on the E3D X Axis Carrier.

Please Note: The image of the BLtouch shown in the renders is not to scale. A genuine BLtouch will have the correct height above the tip of a genuine E3Dv6 Hotend (i.e. 8.3 mm). Users of non-genuine BLtouch sensors may need to make further modifications in order to ensure that the BLtouch is the correct distance above the tip of the hotend. The same applies to users of non-genuine E3D Hotends.

Please support the people who expend their time and money designing and developing these open source hardware items by purchasing the genuine E3D Hotends from e3d-online.com, andthe genuine BlTouch-Smart from antclabs.com.

Should you require a Layer Fan to use with this Thing, I suggest that you have a look at my Front Mount Layer Fan which has been designed for use with this Thing.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula E3Dv6 & BLTouch

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 Layer Height in Cura.

Infill:

20%

All screw holes are printed under size as pilot holes and require drilling to the required size for the type of screws chosen.

For the hardware requirements for mounting the BLtouch, I used 12mm x 3mm Hex Headed Screws, and 3mm nyloc nuts. Do not over tighten.

For other hardware requirements, please refer to the original thing.
The re-mix was done in Fusion 360. As this is a re-mix, I will not be making the Fusion 360 files available for download, without first having Ulmenkott's permission.

title: Alphabet Play Blocks
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
3D printable versions of the old wooden letter/number blocks that we used to play with when I was a little kid. Wow, I'm probably dating myself. I was surprised there didn't seem to be a set of these available on Thingiverse already. (Could be that my search skills just suck.)

There are 6 blocks with a unique letter or number on each face, covering the 26 capital letters A-Z and the 10 digits 0-9. Print a set of 6 if you want every letter and number. Print multiple sets if you want to be able to spell words that use letters on adjacent faces of the same block.

These are incredibly easy to design in most 3D CAD programs. They are just cubes with a letter or number embossed on each face (and edges rounded for safety!). If you are looking for a good starter project, consider designing your own. However, if you just want to print a bunch of blocks for quick play, then here they are!

Full size is 40mm (about 1 5/8") on a side. If you have young children, don't print them much smaller or they might constitute a choking hazard. I don't assume any liability for anything you do, or don't do, with these blocks.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

5% 3D hexagonal

Notes:

I haven't played much with varying the print settings. I found that printing with walls 2 layers thick plus 5% infill is a good combination of durability and quick print speed. Use a structurally sound, isotropic 3D infill pattern like a plain cubic lattice or Slic3r's 3D-hexagon lattice.

If you are using these in an institutional environment where they will see heavy use, consider using thicker and more robust settings for better durability and crush-resistance.

I've only tried printing this in PLA. Other materials might require different settings.
Really easy. Make a cube primitive in almost any CAD program, then extrude/emboss a letter on each face. Nice starter project if you are brand new to CAD like I was not too long ago.

Simple Alphabet Cube Blocks Simple cubic blocks with letters and numbers that can be used for building, spelling, numbers, counting, stacking, adding, subtracting, dividing, etc. Used to be made of wood when I was a kid! Consider printing in different colors to make them more interesting.

A wealth of potential activities for young children Stacking/Engineering: Try to build the highest tower. Try to build a bridge that can pass an object beneath it. Try to build a bigger bridge. Build different shaped towers (e.g. circular ring "grain silo" cross section, square cross section, pyramid, single stack, brick wall, etc) and investigate which one is most resistant to tipping over. Word Play:
-- Challenge children to form a specified word (e.g. D-O-G) from the blocks. (Make sure the word is possible with the set of blocks the child has!) Tailor the word to the abilities of the child. Good for teaching letters and basic word recognition.
-- More advanced/older children can be challenged to come up with their own (real) word using the available letters on their blocks. (Coming up with their own word is a much harder and a more advanced skill since it requires a larger vocabulary to generate possibilities, and good working knowledge of spelling.)
-- Older kids can be given competitive challenges such as seeing who can form the longest word, or be the fastest to form a word of at least four letters. Kids can "roll the dice" and be challenged to come up with a word using only the top faces of each cube. Memory/Logic:
-- Challenge kids to recall from memory what letter is on the bottom of each block.
-- Once children are familiar with the blocks, challenge them to figure out which letter is on the bottom by eliminating the letters visible on the upper surfaces. Arithmetic:
-- Use blocks as units to provide a visual representation of adding and subtracting sums. Alternately, the numbers printed on the blocks can be used for more abstract math.
-- Multiplication concepts can be taught by arranging the blocks in a grid where each axis represents a number to be multiplied. (For example, a grid of 3 by 5 blocks has 15 members, illustrating 3 x 5 = 15.)
-- Division can be illustrated by starting with a known quantity of blocks, then distributing them in round robin fashion into a series of piles (like dealing cards).
-- Probability and statistics: Using blocks like dice, have children tabulate how many throws it takes to get a certain letter, or combination of letters, to show up. Other possibilities:
-- Motor Skills (tossing/rolling): Have the students attempt to toss or roll the blocks from some distance toward a target made of tape on the floor. Alternately, buckets or hoops can be used as targets.
-- Bath/Pool Time: If correctly printed, the blocks should be reasonably waterproof and should float.

Optional Materials A whiteboard, chalkboard, or large pad of paper on an easel may be helpful to write down rules or elements of certain activities. Masking tape may be helpful for creating placement outlines for building/stacking, taping blocks together, or for creating floor targets for tossing activities.
Highly flexible from 5 minutes to an hour or more.

title: ECLIPSE 3D Printable ‘USA and STATE’ PINHOLE PROJECTORS

description.text:
The August 21, 2017 eclipse will be observable across America. While those in the path of totality will see a TOTAL solar eclipse, everyone will be treated to a PARTIAL eclipse! Where will you be? Why not celebrate the eclipse by making your own 3D Printed Pinhole Projector in the shape of the USA and/or of each US State? To see all of NASA's 3D Printable Pinhole Projectors , visit https://eclipse2017.nasa.gov/3d-printable-pinhole-projectors

Ask a friend to take a picture of your shadow while holding your state’s pinhole projector. The resulting image will be a once in a lifetime picture of your shadow, the shadow of your selected state and a projected image of the partial eclipse marking your location!

Share the Moment: Don’t forget to share your best images with us on Instagram, Facebook, Twitter and/or on our Solar Eclipse Flickr Group. Use #EclipseSelfie. Leave a 1-2 sentence description of your image/idea.

author: wcatherall

description.text:
I saw how the cat collars at the pet store cost around $10 and thought I could do it for cheaper.
What is good about this project is that if your cat outgrows or loses their old collar, you can make another one.

The width of the collar strap is around 1 cm but it can be scaled larger if needed.
To get the thickness of the strap I wanted, I cut strip of fabric with a width of 3 inches and folded it inward three times so the part of the fabric that could fray was on the inside.

I then sewed the two sides of the strap and fed it through the respective pieces.

Who wants a Stormy Spinner?

I print with wave bonding. Press the bearing into the spinner, oil spinner and then press the caps on. You are ready to go!

You will need skate bearings. I use these Reds (https://www.amazon.com/Bones-Bearings-Reds/dp/B003U7TQ5U). You might want to oil the bearings. This is an attempt to convert the $99 101Hero Kickstarter printer into a modified Kossel Mini reusing as many of the 101Hero components as possible printed on the 101Hero (Size restrictions less than 110mm diameter and less than 100mm tall).

Note: This does require upgrading the tower motors to NEMA17 but it should be possible to reuse all other components (extruder, belts, steel rods, push rods, linear bearings, controller, etc.)

Current 3D Printed BOM:
3 frame top
3 frame bottom
33 75mm 2020 rails
54 rail connectors (M3 or M4)
90 25mm inner-fill
3 or 6 end caps (optional)

Extra hardware:
54 M3 or M4 nuts (size determined by rail connectors)
54 M3 or M4 x 4mm screws

36 M5 nuts
36 M5x10 hex bolts
If you want to use M3 or M4 bolts, I have included T-Nut models for M3 and M4 nuts. Washers may be required for smaller bolts.

Step 1: Assemble Rails

The 3 tower rails are made up of 4 75mm rails joined at each join with 2 inner-fill and 2 connectors. Total length should be 350mm.

The 9 rails that connect the top frame ends together & the bottom frame ends together are made of 3 75mm rails joined the same way as the tower rails. Total length per rail should be 235mm.

Step 2: Assemble frame top components

Insert 2 M5 bolts into the holes on one side of the frame top and loosely attach 2 M5 nuts.
Slide 2 of the inner fill pieces into slots adjacent to the 5mm nuts so 5mm sticks out.

Slide the M5 nuts into the channel of the 235mm rails and slide the tabs into the slots.

Tighten the M5 bolts (be careful not to crack the pieces)

Do the same thing for the remaining top frame pieces.

Step 3: Assemble frame bottom components

Using the same steps from the frame top, attach 2 235mm rails to the two positions on one side of the bottom frame.

Step 4: Install motors

Attached toothed gear to NEMA 17 motor.
Slide motor shaft into bottom frame and nest the cap of the motor in the cutout.
Attach motor to frame with existing screws from old motor mount.

Repeat for remaining motors.

Step 5: Assemble top & bottom frames

Slide M5 bold and attach nut on remaining rail side of all top & bottom frame components.
Attach 2 inner fill pieces to the unattached end of the 235mm rails. Make sure these are on the same sides as the attached end.
Slide M5 nuts into the slot of the rail and slide the tabs into the grooves of the frame piece.
Tighten the M5 bolts

Step 6: Mount vertical tower rails

Slide two M5x10 bolt through the end of the holes on the curved side of the bottom frame and loosely attach 2 M5 nuts.

Slide the 3 350mm rails into the 2020 slots on the frame bottom (the M5 nuts should slide into the channel of the rail) until they are level with the bottom of the piece.

Tighten the M5 bolts.

More to come ... inserting steel rods More to come ... attaching top frame

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It is a high-speed interceptor that I had designed by myself, with inspiration from the real life Mig-25 Foxbat and Su-27 Flanker. It is, however, just a conceptual model, meant for fun and good display. So do file or sand the sharp edges down before handed to any children. I named the aircraft Z-12A, because I think there are no aircraft designation starts with Z. I hope you have fun and enjoy this thing.

If your slicer have an option to use only "exterior support", then use it, because this could save you a lot of time and work. Using exterior support only means there will be no support structure in between the model. Therefore you will only have to clean up the supports that hold the wing and fuselage.

author: tom7

title: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition) - Hero Tray

description.text:
A tray to organize the Hero items for Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)

Features:
Large flat area for hero card with cut out so you can easily flip it for your Heroic Feat
Slots on left for "Fatigue" - it appears all base characters max out at 5
Slots on top for "Health" - 6 boxes so you can work you way up to the 5 hearts twice
Slots on right to hold items/skill cards
Area in back right corner for hero tokens, etc.
Slots in the side to hold Exhausted cards

Edit 6/6 - Fixed character card size (Print was version one and you can see gap above card that is now fixed) and made exhausted slots into holes to make life easier for removing supports. Also added words to hero tray area.

comments.text: What should the finished dimensions be for this tray?   When I import it into Curia for Wanhao, it is showing up at 204 x 151 x 28mm which is too big for my printer 200 x 200 printer bed.

description.text:
I have a Pentax K1000 camera but don't have a bag to hold film and usually end up trying to hold it in my pockets. I came up with this so that I can change the film quickly.

The strap feeds right through and doesn't get in the way too much when taking pictures.

There is one stl file for cameras with thin (1 cm) straps and another stl file for cameras with thicker (4 cm) straps.

comments.author: mjlawler

comments.text: Hi, thanks for the model. I was able to make one of these and it worked out pretty well. I didn't use any support material and the very top middle of the arch had a single layer that didn't work out out right but other than that there was no issues with printing it. In using it I have found that dice didn't roll that well out of it due to the corners on the inside and also it goes to a flat landing at the bottom before it goes out of the arch.
comments.author: Sam_Q

comments.text: What settings did you use, as when I tried it with my printer the inner and outer walls didn't connect, warped and the sides began to delaminate.
comments.author: SplotchyInk

comments.text: This could be related to the size of the tip being used, for example there is a minimum size bead that can be put down and if the gap between the inner and outer walls is less than this the printer can't physically put something down in the middle. Apparently some software is better at trying to overcome this than others. Using either a smaller or larger tip should help. I also had a gap and I used a 0.4mm tip. In my experience I have found that if I had a model with a 2mm wall thickness it will have a gap but when I re-designed it to be 1.6m thick it didn't.
comments.author: SplotchyInk

comments.text: I don't remember exactly what settings I used for this print, but I generally use Kisslicer with natural PLA filament. My settings are usually .2mm layer height, 10% infill, .4mm extrusion width, no support, 190c temp. I hope that helps, but please let me know if I can help you more. I've printed three of these now for myself and friends with no issue yet.
comments.author: SplotchyInk

comments.text: I can see PLA working because it's bonds with itself very easily.  However I'm not having much luck using XT.  The perimeter walls being 2 layers wide, side by side, with nothing to connect them causes them to de-laminate.  I'm playing with settings but I'm guessing it won't work.  It probably needs the walls to be thicker for PET type materials.

Wombot BL Touch Calibration Tool, this adjust your BL Touch to be 1mm above you Nozzle.
Lower Nozzle gently so it touches the round section, DON'T Drive the Nozzle to hard, just enough so there No movement, than lower the BL Touch onto the round 20mm section which is 1mm higher than the Nozzle.

Bring Nozzle down to 3mm from bed via Z offset, while the BL Touch will be 4mm off bed.
Please do this Calibration when your Nozzle has cool down.

This is an industrial style lamp we design for our Laboratory in Milan. No one shared something similar in the Community, so we decided to project one big dimension lamp, but full optimized for 3D printing: NO support required, easy to print, solid and functional. It' not an easy target because usually the old lamps had a large cup, but we divided it in two to give a more interesting look with a six screw assembly, and to be able to generate the LampB file in "spiralize the outer contour"(light diffusion). In this way, you save a lot of time to print it.
Please note you need two steel bars, the upper one with bolts, to hang safely the lamp to the cieling. You can see them in the last picture (the red ones) and in the pictures of the printed object. Diameter 8 mm.
All the best!

Notes:

Print all the parts with a big machine, 400x400 area. NO SUPPORT required!
IMPORTANT: to create a solid object, print all with a 0.8 Nozzle size and 0.4 Layer high. It will be very sturdy. The Spiralized object is made in transparent PLA (big nozzle anyway) but it could be created in PETG or similar transparent filaments.

After the printing, mount all the stuff with some parker screw or anything you like to give it an "industrial look". Before to print, is better to paint and maybe give an antique finish to all the "metallic" parts. Use a simple electric wire and choose the kind of light you like.

Yet another coin fidget spinner. This one is a biggy. It uses 32 20 euro cent coins, in 8 stacks à 4 coins.
The centre hole is for the standard 608 skate bearing, 22 mm × 7 mm.

There are a two ready-made STLs, the one i have printed, and one without the notches, giving it a wheel-like appearance.

This is slightly parametric. Whit a bit of work you can use your favourite coins, either local currencies, or parts of that pile of foreign currency that travellers tend to collect. (Admittedly, for this one you need a big pile to have 32 identical foreign coins.) I have included the FreeCAD files. They include a spreadsheet called “sizes”. To get a new spinner, do this:

  • Download FreeCAD and get it running
  • Load the yacs_mega.fcstd or yacs_mega_wheel.fcstd FreeCAD file
  • In the tree view, double click on “Sizes”. You should see the spreadsheet
  • Measure your coin or look up its size (Wikipedia, search engine, &c.)
  • Put in the diameter and thickness in B6 and B7. Make sure to keep the = and mm.
  • Check that you have enough coins. The spreadsheet shows the number needed. Typically 32
  • Change other values in the “B” column, like the whole spinner’s size, to taste.
  • Go back to, wlog, the yacs_mega view
  • Check that the shown shape looks OK. There are view controls at the top
  • Check that in the tree view there are no exclamation marks as warnings
  • If there are problems, it’s easiest to close without saving and to try again. Change fewer values, and only by small amounts.
  • If the spinner looks good, select the last item, “spinner”. It should turn green in the main view.
  • Look for the dropdown in the tool bar and select “Mesh Design”
  • You should now have a “Meshes” menu. Select “Create mesh from shape …”
  • I have to select the “Standard” radio button. “Mefisto” produces empty meshes.
  • Click OK
  • There should be a “spinner (Meshed)” item in the tree view. Select it.
  • Click on the “Export a mesh to file” icon, enter a file name, select file type (STL or OBJ) and click “OK”,
  • Et voilà, you’re done. You have finished your first FreeCAD lesson and can now go ahead and slice and print your customized spinner.

If you want to increase the total size, you should probably remove the lightening holes, but how to do this goes beyond this description.

There is also some design history available at my github repo.

All my “yacs” spinners (there are more to come) are related and started out with the same bearing ring.

I wanted to put a camera on the rover, so I bought a small one like this: http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/USB-5MP-HD-Webcam-Web-Cam-Camera-for-Computer-PC-Laptop-Desktop-UK-/222535768482

I stripped it down to remove the PCB and lens then designed a more compact mounting for it. It screws onto the pan-tilt head https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1642426 with self-tapping screws (i.e. directly into the plastic).

This is a USB camera, so you need a Raspberry PI or similar to connect it to and stream the video.

Note that the lag is very large, up to several seconds, so not really suitable for FPV-equivalent solutions.

It is specifically designed for this type of camera is it directly mounts the inner PCB and lens assembly. I wouldn't expect it to work with other cameras without modification.

title: Raspberry Pi mounting bracket for Martian Rover

description.text: This is a mounting bracket that fits inside the Martian Rover to allow a Raspberry Pi to be installed and the circuit board held securely. There are also mounting points for the motor speed controllers (held in with tie wraps), a dual-channel relay board (as seen in the picture) and a 5V switch mode regulator under the PI to provide a stable 5v from the 7V LiPo battery. I used a TI LMZ31710EVM board because I had it lying around but it's quite big... there are much smaller ones on ebay. I use one of the relays driven off the motor speed controller regulator to turn on and off the power to the Pi.

title: igus replacement for Prusa I3 MK2(s)

description.text:
This is an replacement for the original Prusa I3 MK2 x-axis parts fitting the igus RJZM-01-08 and RJZM-02-08 bearings. For the x-carriage I use the RJZM-01-08 (16mm), for die x-end_idler and x-end_motor (z-axis) the RJZM-02-08 (15mm). I also fixed some errors in the mesh of the original parts and an old bug in the x-carriage that the belt is rubbing on the idler.

If you looking for a good y-axis bearing replacement, take this one https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1837936

Please use original igus SWM-08 rods too, other rods didn't not work well because there is much space between the bearings and the rods ! Recommended lenght for the rods :
2x 320mm, 2x 330mm and 2x 370mm

Be careful, the x-carriage is for the MK2, It will work for the MK2s too, but with the old disadvantages.

Update :
fixed another belt rubbing at the carriage

Notes:

I printed all parts with support, but it is not mandatory. I printed the parts with Polymaker PC plus.

Remove parts from support if you printed it with support.

The bearings fits very well, so you need some force to press it in. Be careful, use the right bearings for the different axises !

igus lubrication

The igus bearings must be aligned very well, otherwise it's going too strong. If you use original igus SWM-08 it is maybe possible that the rods are rusting. In this case, and only in this case, you can lubricate it with some silicone spray.

author: Mickmcl16

description.text:
The Lords of the Beyond after being banished left behind a large strip of devastated land, with ghost towns, buildings, temples and a whole range of localities. Rumors that in these places existed treasures, weapons and a whole range of fantastic things, began to arrive in the ears of the people of our world.

Individuals in search of fame and fortune have decided to enter these cursed lands in search of these prizes. Organized in small groups, they enter these lands and there they face dangers. This is the premise of Scavengers, a skirmish game in the devastated lands, where you lead a group of adventurers in search of fame and fortune.

Extracted from Alabar Chronicle´s, a Scavenger Guide to Our World"

Introduction

Scavengers is a table top miniature war game for fighting skirmishes with fantasy/steampunk figures. Two players fight a small scale combat with five to ten miniatures on each side (a hero and your henchmen). The game is easy to learn and play, though there is enough depth that it will take time and experience to master.

The game was designed around three core premises.

a) You can download our 3D models or use any miniatures in their collection. Thus, the game is not specifically designed to any particular manufacturer or company. But if you like to help the game dev, please download our models! (They are free and paid...)

b) It is important that the miniatures on the table be the focus of the game. In the end, miniature gaming should be about miniatures (and fun!)

c) A large background - We´ll develop new units, histories and game scenarios. But we need your help, sending suggestions to improve the game!

I hope you like our game and have fun! Ahh, an important thing: this is the basic core rules, our idea is releasing other books to improve the game!

This is an orc airship and you need to print 1 for a stand. Our gaming site is coming with our core book, game lore and a lot of new things!

author: ramono

title: Old gas pump style AC adaptor cover for Sphero Lightning McQueen

description.text:
Missing piece for your beloved car !

Sphero’s Lightning McQueen is an awesome robotic toy with every detail is intact. I especially like the idea of wired charging with red cable which mimics fuel hose, so I push that idea even further and this old gas pump style AC adaptor cover was born.

I designed it so that small 3D printer like M3D Micro can handle without support. But I noticed the slicer integrated in the M3D software cannot process the whole data (OldGasPump_All.stl) correctly, and that is why I prepared the separated files (OldGasPump_MainUnit.stl, OldGasPump_PlugHolder.stl, OldGasPump_PricePanel.stl, OldGasPump_Sign.stl). So if you encounter the same problem or use different color filaments for some parts, please use those files.
Also, please print OldGasPump.png on a gloss paper, cut them out and paste them on the respective parts.

If you use PLA and want apply adhesive to fix small perts, I recommend to use one for acrylic resin. Just one drop melts the surface of PLA and fix them well, but ventilate well and handle with care. Adhesive for acrylic resin also works for ABS, but it hard to find good adhesive for PLA, so I wanted to add this info.

You have 2 ways to use this cover (Please see the usage images). Either way, Please set the outside cable length first, and manage the cable inside. The inside space is tight, but the rest of the cable can be packed in the case as you can see in the photo.
WARNING : Use this cover at your own risk. I have no problem using it so far, but rolled cable may produce heat. Please disconnect the adopter from an AC outlet when not in use.

Note for M3D Micro user : Please disable “Enable skirt” when you print OldGasPump_All.stl or OldGasPump_MainUnit.stl, otherwise they won’t fit in the build plate. Do not worry. Although it says skirt is recommended, you can print them fine. You might encounter slight curl of the front panel, which is located bottom when printed, but it adds some good nuance to the pump.

Printer:

M3d Micro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

This is a remix of the steam locomotive by gluetolf, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:422024
I only included the stl's for my modifications the locomotive itself should be downloaded separately.
I made connecting rods for the drive wheels and a moving piston ram and drive rod. It now has a realistic movement when the wheels are turning.
Please read the post printing notes below for assembly tips.

Printer:

Hictop Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

100%

Axles and trunnions need to be fitted to the wheels rods. They should be a light press fit into the wheels, no adhesive needed. The rods should move freely on their pivots. I used a small file set to accomplish this. There are stl's for trunnion shafts both with and without the caps printed on them, use which ever is easiest for you while assembling. The trunnion spacer thickness may need to be adjusted, these are necessary for clearances so the moving parts cannot interfere with each other. Wheel spacers are also necessary on all wheels.
When installing the wheels to the axles, orient the opposite side wheel trunnions at 90 degree offset for smooth operation while rolling. This will insure the driven wheels cannot reverse rotation at the beginning and end of the stroke.

comments.author: ElMery

comments.text: Made this because I thought it would really test my machine. Well, in use there is just no way the filament will stay in the bottom rollers as pictured. Pops out every time. I even tried looping the filament behind the top roller and in front of the bottom one. No joy. There is just too much drag on the filament without going through the two bottom rollers. I just took it all off and went back to the stand that came with the machine.
comments.author: BusterCrabb

comments.text: I going into the same problem, because my first filament role shrink in diameter and will end soon. The problem is, that the diameter of the filament shrink and the extruder need more force to pull down the filament. My idea to solve this problem was to increase the diameter of the puleys to increase the lever arm of the pulleys to decrease the friction. I try it yesterday, but the friction is to big. I have a idea to construct and print a kind of a ball-bearing and hope the the friction decrease again. I will plan it on this  weekend.
comments.author: BusterCrabb

comments.text: While I applaud your tenacity in trying to get this to work, I do not believe it is worth the time, effort and material. It's just too complex a design for its intended use. The filament will never stay put between the bottom rollers without serious modification of the design.

title: Dean's Geodesic Dome and N-gon Pyramid Maker

description.text:
As part of on-going collaboration with the Crawford School of Art and Design in the area of 3D printing we are producing parts to be used by, Dean O'Connor, a final year student in his work. Some pictures of the installed piece are included here. Link to Dean's page on Crawford School of Art and Design's exhibitions website:
http://crawfordexhibitions.com/exxit/?portfolio=dean-oconnor
Link to his Blog: http://deanoconnorartist.blogspot.com/ In this case we are making flat triangular shapes to be used to construct a large geodesic dome as part of a piece on the un-realised promises of utopian architecture (or so is my engineering brain's understanding of the piece). The piece will be translucent enough to allow internal projection of colours or images to show through to the outside surface. As part of illustrating the theme of unrealised utopian dwellings the piece will attempt to show the imperfections of manufacture and assembly that appear as a result of its imperfect creation. So that means we need to actually ensure some of the features and flaws possible with 3d printing (such as curling, build platform surface texture, bits of torn kapton stuck in the first layer, residual colours from other prints, honeycomb pattern, gaps, printed surface texture) are included or even accentuated in these pieces... which is an interesting an unusual request! The photographs of all the triangles prepared were all printed on the same machine with the same white plastic. The different colours and tones come from various sources including: black marks drawn on the filament to ensure the filament is being drawn into the extruder correctly, pieces of different colour plastic being left on or falling onto the build platform and being incorporated into the print, Kapton tape unintentionally incorporated into the build, white ABS glue used to patch over small tears in the build platform, acetone and white ABS putty used to repair damaged pieces. A simple geodesic dome can be made with triangles joined edge to edge. In this case 10 equilateral triangles and 30 isosceles triangles. The isosceles triangles form 6 pentagonal pyramids. The equilateral triangles fill in the gaps. The dome will be about 30cm (1 foot) in diameter. To make it transparent enough to allow the projection to show through to the other side the parts will have to be very thin. The original idea was to use totally flat triangles of 2 or 3 layers thickness which could be assembled like paper craft models. However, these tended to bend when being removed from the build platform, curled up at the corners, were difficult to assemble and were not very strong once assembled! The design was modified to include the following features:
  • mouse-ears at apexes to prevent curling
  • a thick rim around the edges to provide a large bonding area for strength when assembled and resist bending when removed from build platform
  • angled edges to make for easier assembly, with the angle chosen to ensure the edges meet at the correct angle for assembling pentagons
  • a triangular cutout giving a thin central region to enhance transparency
    • Expected print time on a Thing-o-matic is about 20 minutes per piece or 13 hours in total! O_O;

These scripts can be used to make individual triangles or single piece, snap and fold together items that you can use to easily make n-gon pyramids. These can be combined to make a full geodesic dome, or some other interesting shapes. The file "2012_05_25-Deans_dome_pentagon_test-3.scad" is the most up-to-date and allows you to make any of the items described easily by setting a few control variables at the top of the file to 0 or 1. Everything is fully commented and should be easy to follow. Please note: If you choose impossible combinations of values (such as a pyramid made of 8 equilateral triangles) openscad will likely crash horribly! Make your own sized parts:
  • Download relevant .scad files and modify triangle_length_a and triangle_length_b variables to match the size of the triangle/n-gon pyramid/dome you want to make (if you want to make a functioning dome you will need to keep the provided ratio of triangle lengths, also as a rough guide the dome diameter will be about 3 times the triangle length)
  • Modify other variables such as rim_t, rim_w, centre_t and number_of_triangles to suit the object you wish to build
  • Modify mouse_ear_thickness and mouse_ear_radius to suit your printer
  • Generate .stl file and print your object(s)
    • Assemble dome from parts:
  • Download provided or use scad scripts to make your own sized parts
  • Print 10x equilateral triangles
  • Print 30x isosceles triangles
  • Clean up printed parts
  • Assemble isosceles triangles into pentagonal based pyramids by bonding along their long edges with the ribs facing inwards (ABS dissolved in acetone is a good glue to use for ABS, for PLA use superglue)
  • Assemble pentagonal based pyramids into dome shape by bonding 5 pyramids to each edge of the last remaining one.
  • Fill in the holes using the 10 equilateral triangles
  • Use additional acetone/glue to ensure seams are well bonded
  • Use for... whatever a (potentially) un-fulfilled utopian architectural promise should be used for

comments.text: You're welcome and I look forward to seeing pictures!
comments.author: M_G

comments.text:
I just started looking at printing a model made from your scad files but I'm having a problem when I change the number of triangles up to 10. When I change number of triangles from 9 to 10 in 2012_05_25-Deans_dome_pentagon_test-3.scad, the angle_tilt3, scaling_factor, and extra_height in the debug output become "nan" (Not A Number?). If I hit F6 to compile I see "Warning: Transformation matrix contains Not-a-Number and/or Infinity - removing object." I've tried it in OpenSCAD 2013-01 and 2014-03 and both fail.
Here's what I'm trying to accomplish... I have been making papercraft planet globes but they're too fragile to let kids hold so I was thinking of printing an n-gon to fit inside the paper to give them more structural strength. The paper templates I'm using are from a German site and they appear to be 120 sided for the smaller planets like Earth and Mars.
Source site: http://sternwarte-recklinghausen.de/interaktiv/bastelboegen/http://sternwarte-recklinghaus...
The planet models are under "Die Planeten" and are in PDF format.
comments.author: lowlight

comments.text:
Hello lowlight,
You get these errors when you try to generate a shape that self intersects (i.e. it flat would cover more than 360 degrees) or that cannot be folded up into a simple "pyramid" type shape. You will need to adjust the triangle_length_a, triangle_length_b or number_of_triangles values to make a valid shape (I would recommend reducing the triangle_length_a value until you get somethign generated).
Having looked at the file for Uranus and Earth on the website you linked it appears that these are not the same type of dome that my code is designed to make anyhow (as this code is based on using a mix of isosceles and equilateral triangles). Even so it SHOULD still be able to make something that works, but it may require some trial and error.
Looking closely at the files, they are not REALLY 120 sided objects, they are more like a 60 sided object. The whole planet is split into 12 groups composed of 5 shapes that are almost isosceles triangles, although one of these almost triangles is split in half and the bottom edges of each almost triangle has an additional shallow vertex. When roughly measured off my computer screen these almost triangles appear to be 50mm along the bottom edge and 84mm along the other two edges. Setting triangle_length_a=95, triangle_length_b=84 and number_of_triangles=5 will generate something that looks right.
IF you want to still generate a10 sided shape to actually make a 120 sided planet try setting triangle_length_a=50, triangle_length_b=84 and number_of_triangles=10, this seems to generate something that looks about right. Although I don't know how well it will fit together to make a 3d planet!
Good luck and be sure to upload a picture of a completed sphere if you manage to get it to work.
comments.author: lowlight

comments.text: Thanks so much for giving such a detailed reply and not just ignoring me since you uploaded the model over 2 years ago. :)  I'll definitely upload some pictures if I get it to work.
comments.author: M_G

THIS IS WHAT THE INSIDE OF YOUR HEAD LOOKS LIKE!
Oh, sorry for shouting, I just get really... "passionate" when it comes to learning. The head part of this was a 3D scan of my friend Jack.
And then the skull was taken from some skull model that was on thingiverse. I invite you all to make new models showing what other things look like on the inside such as: Animals, People, Plants, Buildings, Robots, anything!!
What sort of crazy cross-section models can you make??

I printed this in 2 different parts and just glued them together.
But the STL files are set up so if you have a printer with dual extruders, you could merge them and do a dual-extrusion print probably..... Although you will want to use full supports. USE SUPPORTS!!!
This thing is gonna require full supports.

title: Angle Grinder Chop Saw for EMT Conduit and 2020 Extrusion
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Looking for a better way to cut 3/4" EMT conduit, I could buy an expensive blade for my reciprocating saw or find a better way. I saw an angle grinder mount and decided to make my own to fit the grinder I have.
UPDATE -- added a guide for 2020 extrusion.

WARNING: use at your own risk. Be safe.

If you find this useful and want to encourage my insanity, buy a cup of coffee for me, a bag of coffee, or you pick the value. Thanks!

I made mount for my over 10 years old Harbor Fright angle grinder and it works well. Then I ran across a coupon for a new Harbor Fright angle grinder for $10. I made a mount for the new one, too.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2-0.25mm layers

Infill:

25-60% -- 4 or more outlines

Notes:

Designed to be printed without supports and with close tolerances.

PLA seems strong enough for the prints I made. PETG may be better.

Designed for Harbor Freight Angle Grinder model #69645 -- often on sale for $15 or less with a coupon. Also, have a clamp for my, much older, #03150 grinder.

Needed hardware:
1 - 1/4-20 1-1/2" hex bolt
1 - 1/4-20 wing nut
2 - 1/4 - 1" fender washers
2 - #6-32 3/4" screws
2 - #6 washers
2 - #6-32 nut
7 - #8 1-1/4" deck screws
1 rubberband
12" section of 2x4

Insert the #6 screws into the washers and into the holes on the clamp. Add the nuts to the opposite side and tighten down pulling the nuts into the pockets.

Loosen the screws and open the clamp up.

Wrap the rubberband around the end of the grinder once or twice
Place the clamp part over the rubberband on the grinder. May not be necessary for new grinder, but my old one needed a little extra grip.

Tighten the screws down evenly. Make sure the grinder is held securely.

Using 4 deck screws, screw the base into the end of the 2x4 section.

Next, start the hex bolt in the base--on the side with the hex hole. Add a washer, the clamp, and then the other washer. Push the bolt all the way through and tighten with the wing nut.

Finally, with the grinder with the cutoff wheel attached, lower it and align the conduit guide so the conduit would be aligned where needed.

Be safe.

description.text: An unnecessarily fancy spool holder. Spool width is adjustable using an M10 threaded rod. An M8 rod will also work.

Materials:
1x Outer Left.stl
1x Inner Left.stl
1x Inner Right.stl
1x Outer Right.stl
4x M10 washer
4x M10 nut
1x M10 rod, wide enough for your spool There are four pieces to print - each side of the spool holder is printed from two halves with interlocking pegs. Depending on the size of your build plate you may need to rotate the object 45Â° to make it fit. The pegs fit into holes in the mating half. They are a tight fit and once they go together they won't come apart without breaking the pegs. A note on print settings for the two inner halves - make sure you have a suitable solid infill threshold area and a low minimum print speed for layers with not much material (you will find this in the cooling section of filament settings in slic3r). These settings are important for getting good quality on the mating pegs.

title: "Typhoon" Twin 30mm Part Cooling for Frankenstein E3D Hot End

description.text: A modification for the Frankenstein E3D carriage used on the Anet A6. I have been using the stock Frankenstein carriage design and so far so good. My biggest complaint would have to be the single fan that for me struggles to deliver optimum part cooling on both sides of my nozzle. This replaces the shroud and 40mm fan with a shroud featuring twin 30mm fans that each direct air into their respective channels. No more splitting one air input between two exit paths. Simply replace the top most part of the cooling assembly and mount your twin fans. I use a JST connector to mate the fan units and both work excellent. I can already see a difference in my overhang quality and I recommend you to see the difference for yourself.

comments.text:
Hi. I saw your video with the comparison between fanducts. IT is good, and your method is pretty consistent.
I hav tested, and Im not exagerating, like a dozen of funducts, till I got tired of seem similar results in most of them. Most fails is the same issue: they dont distribute the air evenly, and a couple of the funducts you tested fails in that too, like the cicular, the dutched, etc.
This funducts produce good result most of the times, but in certain situations, this failure in distrubuteing the air evenly, shows up. You should include in your test, a circular overhang test. This way, when the circular object is being printed 1 side of the object overhang will not receive a good cooling. My test were done first looking at the air distribution useing a radial fan of course, powering up at 50% (that is a lot of air) and putting below a cup of water. When you aprouch the funduct to the water, you will start seeing howmuch and from what direction the air impacts in the water.
Also, I have to mention this: there is only 1 design that achieve a perfect air flow around the 360 degrees: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1025471
ANd the reason is pure design , looking at the interior you can see structures that distributes the air evenly.
To be sincere, I skiped testing a similar desing of your funduct, because I asumed I was going to get similar results liek in the circular duct. But I will give it a try now . What I like in your design is that is small.

author: Casifish

title: Scherrzither (German kind of a Drone Zither)

description.text:
This is a CNC project.

I play the Scherrzither since a few years and i wanted to build one by myself. So i searched the Web, wondering if there were already published building Instructions by someone.
Nope... no instructions... even no Models!

So i made my own Design in FreeCAD.
At present i have made a "dirty-hack" version to check if my CAD-Version of the Scherrzither is working in real life. so far it looks good! The Fretboard is accurate
so far but I'm searching for a better alternative for the Frets. I used 1mm iron sheet from a PC-Housing, but it's too sharp-edged.

Mor information about Scherrzithers here:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scheitholt
https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scherrzither

..or my Uncle Playing: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FDnnuv8CnWM

Design

I used FreeCAD for the design process, exported the parts as Flattened SVG and used the excellent EstlCAM for the CNC-Programs.

Material

I had a 19mm Spruce Plywood and some 4mm Cottonwood plywood Sheets lying around. The Fretboard was made out of a birch-made baseboard.

I looted an old and damaged concert-Zither that i found on a yard-sale for the tuners.

author: StreetPiet

description.text: Wheely, Pullus Sine Fuga Ex Machina. Wheely is a domesticated subspecies of the common Flightless Aircraft. Found in the disused aerodromes of the southwestern deserts, Wheelies descend from earlier generations of autonomous UAV's. They live in rigorously organized communities called squadrons and spend most of their lives socializing. Largely ambivalent to other mechanical organisms, Wheely retains his ancestors ability to detect electric fields. Created By Michael Curry (Skimbal)

Wheely is intended as a project for the skilled maker. To complete this project, you will need to read a circuit diagram, solder a wiring harness, upload a sketch to an Arduino, and assemble a precisely designed Japanese gearbox.
Printing on the MakerBot Replicator takes approximately 30 hours, and assembly time is 4 to 6 hours.
Refer to Wheely Instructions.pdf for detailed assembly instructions.
-Michael Curry (Skimbal)

title: Makerfarm Magma Hotend Fan Duct w/ Auto-Bed Leveling Servo Mount and LED's

description.text:
Designed/Inspired from various other designs as a fan ducting for Makerfarm printers using the Magma Hotend and Auto-Bed Leveling. There is also a version with holes for flush mounted 5mm LED's to the inside of the ducting. For the Z-Probe holder I used Zennmasters Design, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:167430/#files,
but due to the tight fit I had to take a sliver off the top where it connects to the servo. Parametric 9g Servo mount for Makerfarm i3 with auto bed leveling
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:167440
MakerFarm Prusa i3 Magma cooling system remix
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:161066
Customized Makerfarm i3 X-Carriage
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:232872

Forewarning, this can be a pain to assemble!!!!!
But, once its in place it is so nice to have. When it comes to mounting this to the carriage, I first wired in the LED's with a bit of slack in the cables to allow the wire to run around the hotend without touching, then applied a bit of super glue to hold the LED's in place on the ducting. At this point both the Left and right pieces will be connected but only by the wires attached to the LED's. In order to get the right Duct in I had to take the nut and pre-thread it around the length of the spacing in the wooden mount. I then worked the ducts around the hotend till i could attach the right duct. and tightened it down,it should fit in nice and easy. Now to get the left in make sure the servo is not attached and work the left side into place, with the nut pre-threaded to match the slot in the ducting. Once you get it in, this can be tricky, line up the bases and tighten it in place making sure the base locks into the clips. The clips might break, not a big deal, once the fan adapter is on it should hold it in place well enough. In order to get the servo and endstop on, I pre-attached the endstop to the probe then fed the probe threw the servo hole giving enough room to tighten the probe to the servo. Once it is tightened I just fed the servo-probe back threw the servo mount hole. I had to take a sliver of plastic off the probe in order to get it to fit back threw the mount hole. Then just screw down the servo and make some minor adjustments. Once the ducting is in place take fan adapter, fan, and fan cover and screw them in place. Make sure the adapter is holding the base of the ducting in place, at which point you should be done.

author: Willis123

description.text:
More information at http://pear-cnc.com/support/en

This is 3d printed CNC router, strongly inspired by MPCNC and MPCNC LowRider. I wanted to have rigid as possible machine, with larger z axis height, with equal power on X and Y axes.
Most parts are 3d printed. Few of them (flat plates) are cutted by mpcnc from 6mm MDF.
To build it you need M8 screws, m4 screws, M8 M4 nylon nuts, 608rs or 608zz bearings, m8 and m4 rods.
I found best results in quality and durability of 3d printed parts by using PET-G filament.

Tool mount is compatible with MPCNC tool mount
Designed for 25mm rails
As controller I use Arduiono Mega 2560, Ramps 1.4 with DRV8825 stepper drivers, 5 nema17 stepper motors 59 N-cm/83 oz-in.
I added to marlin firmware menu two commands. G92 X0 Y0 Z0 which resets all coordinates and G92 Z0 which reset only Z axes coordinate. G92 Z0 is helpful during tool change.

If you downloaded please give a like and share

title: Linear Rail alignment helper for MGN12 + V-Slot 2020
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple tool to help with aligning MGN12 linear rails on V-slot 2020 extrusions. Made this for my Anycubic Delta Kossel Linear Plus to improve build quality and precision of the printer.

  1. Loosen all screws of the rail first (don't remove them entirely obviously, or the nuts will drop into the extrusions).
  2. Slowly slide on the clamps (I suggest using three) carefully straightening the rail in the process.
  3. Re-tighten the screws and remove the clamps.
  4. Don't forget to calibrate the printer and enjoy!

See photos for further information on how to slide these on/use them.

Taront3rD

title: PCB Heatbed MK2a Plate (4 hole mounting) (DXF)

description.text:
After showing the 3 hole mounting version for my printer to a couple of friends, a few of them mentioned that they would love a 4 hole mounting option, so here it is.
3mm Aluminium should do well for your printing surface on top of your PCB MK2a Heatbed. It's 214mm x 214mm with cut-outs for the set screws and electrical connections on a Reprap PCB Heatbed MK2a which will be mounted with 4 posts.
3 hole version here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:236148 but I think this version should work on a 3 hole mounted bed as well.
Ref: http://reprap.org/wiki/PCB_Heatbed#About_the_MK2a
Update: Version 2 - After having these cut, all seems to fit well and really tight except that I made a mistake with the cut-out for the electronics. Version 2 the gap is really 80mm wide instead of 70mm in the original. If you use your heatbed with the copper side down, the original may still work fine which is why I left the .dxf file.
Version 2.1
I added a tab about 15mm x 5mm sticking out near one of the corners to allow for it to be easily lifted off because this plate is exactly the same size as the heatbed.
Version 2.2
Minor update: Sharp corners in the electronics cut out. Easy bubble free Kapton tape: http://youtu.be/HahEdDYf7wQ Gineer R&D
